generation0.passage:
The Great Wall of China is one of the most famous landmarks in the world.
It stretches over 13,000 miles and winds through mountains, deserts, and grasslands.
But why was it built?
The Great Wall was mainly built to protect China from invaders, especially from the north.
Long ago, different Chinese dynasties added to the wall over hundreds of years.
The most well-known part was built during the Ming Dynasty, about 600 years ago.
It was made using bricks and stones, and it was strong enough to last for centuries.
Thousands of workers helped build the wall.
Some were soldiers, while others were farmers forced to work.
It was hard, dangerous labor.
Many people died while building it.
That’s why the wall is sometimes called "the world’s longest cemetery."
The wall also helped with communication.
Watchtowers were placed along the wall.
If enemies were seen, soldiers used smoke during the day or fire at night to send warnings.
Today, the Great Wall is a symbol of China’s strength and history.
Millions of people visit it each year.
While some parts are broken or worn down, other sections have been repaired for tourists.
The Great Wall is not just a wall—it’s a piece of history that tells the story of a powerful civilization and the people who built it.
